question: Question_A_24
statement:
Questions A22-A24 concern a random walk with three states that has
transition matrix

\begin{align*}\left[\begin{array}{c c c} 8/10 & 3/10 & 1/10 \\ 2/10 & 3/10 & 7/10 \\ 0 & 4/10 & 2/10 \end{array}\right]\end{align*}

What is the equilibrium probability vector for the random walk?
sols:
From the hint we see that a probability equilibrium vector gives us the
probabilities of a final state from any initial state. This means that
once we transition to a certain point, further transitions do not impact
the probability any more. Let's assume we have reached this special
equilibrium vector \textbf{v} then

\begin{align*}P\mathbf{v}=\mathbf{v}\end{align*}

which says exactly what we stated; attempting to transition \textbf{v}
does nothing to it. Therefore the special vector \textbf{v}, will
satisfy

\begin{align*}
(P-I)\mathbf{v}&=\mathbf{0}\\
\begin{bmatrix}
-2/10  &  3/10  &  1/10\\
2/10  &  -7/10  &  7/10\\
0  &  4/10  &  -8/10
\end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix}
v_1\\
v_2\\
v_3
\end{bmatrix}
&=\begin{bmatrix}
0\\
0\\
0
\end{bmatrix}\end{align*}

which we can solve (using Gaussian elimination) to get, for a free
parameter, t,

\begin{align*}\mathbf{v}=\left[\frac{7}{2}t,2t,t\right].\end{align*}

Now recall that the input vector \textbf{v} is a set of probabilities
and so the entries of \textbf{v} must sum to 1. Therefore we have that,

\begin{align*}v_1+v_2+v_3=\frac{7}{2}t+2t+t=\frac{13}{2}t=1\end{align*}

and therefore, t=2/13 so that our equilibrium vector \textbf{v} is

\begin{align*}\mathbf{v}=\left[\frac{7}{13},\frac{4}{13},\frac{2}{13}\right].\end{align*}

\textbf{\emph{Note}} \emph{(This is not necessary to answer the
question):} Our result means that starting from any initial state, we
will end up in state 1 with a probability of 7/13, state 2 with a
probability of 4/13 and state 3 with a probability of 2/13. If we try
this with our initial state from
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2011/Question_A23}{A
23}, {[}0,1,0{]} we notice that after 8 transitions,

\begin{align*}\displaystyle{}P^8[0,1,0]=[0.5309904100,0.3114556300,0.1575539600]\end{align*}

where our equilibrium vector is

\begin{align*}\mathbf{v}=[0.5384615385,0.3076923077,0.1538461538]\end{align*}

which is already a fairly good agreement!

\textbf{\emph{Note further:}} It may have crossed some minds that the
equilibrium vector is always the eigenvector for the transition matrix
corresponding to an eigenvalue of 1, whose entries sum to 1. For
probability matrices where the columns sum to 1 there will always be
such a vector.
hints:
An equilibrium probability vector is one such that if you were try to
perform a transition, it wouldn't move. Physically it represents the
final probabilities of ending up in a given state from any initial
state.
